Description: Lower body and ring foot sherd of South Ionian pottery cup, possibly a cup with everted rim; interior: dot and two circles on reserved tondo, glazed around; exterior: lowest wall and outside of foot reserved, glazed above; underside of foot very worn; once wholly glazed save band around outside; inscription on underside.
Type series: Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B2 (possibly)
Curator's comments: The lack of a rim prevents a definitive identification of the cup as a South Ionian cup with everted rim. However, the fabric and pattern find parallels with Hayes' Ionian Cup Type VIII (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116). Hayes' Type VIII is of the same shape as his Type IX (only the interior decoration is different) which coincides with Schlotzhauer's (Schlotzhauer 2012) Type 9A and Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B2 (Vallet and Villard, 1964, 87-88). Type 9 cups have been found in large numbers in other sanctuary settings including at the Sanctuary of Aphrodite at Miletus and the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra. This type was the most common type of South Ionian cups with everted rims found at Naukratis. The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape. Unusually in this instance, the foot (or what remains of it) is reserved. Typically, the foot on such cups is glazed black.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.311) (Phase 3)
